http.title: Mozilla guide to HTTP
http.description: The home page with references to all things HTTP

http.title: An overview of HTTP
http.description: A high level overview covering the core concepts of HTTP

http.title: HTTP Headers
http.description: An explanation of HTTP Headers. You will learn about standard headers and custom headers and how both can be used in client/server interactions

http.title: HTTP Request Methods
http.description: An explanation of HTTP Request Methods. As you progress into learning about REST and building Restful APIs the information here will be invaluable to you

http.title: HTTP Status
http.description: Explanation of HTTP Status codes and their classifications. Status codes are used to convey the outcome of a request.  Web Apps and the APIs they are built with, can react differently to handle different response codes, especially so in error handling type scenarios.  Having an understand of the codes can help you to decipher problems arising from calling a web service or about the type of response code you should be using if building a web service of your own

http.title: Access-Control and CORS
http.description: An Explanation of the Access-Control header and Cross Origin HTTP Requests (CORS). One of the first things that is most likely to trip you up in your web development journey.  But with the knowledge you have gained from the earlier sections, this should make far more sense

http.title: Analysing a network trace for a web application in Google Chrome
http.description: Now you know all about HTTP, you should learn about the client side tooling to assist with network analysis.  Make sure you've completed all of the above reading. Go to your favourite website or Web API in Google Chrome, turn on the Chrome Developer Tools and use it to analyse the network trace.  Look at the request and response details,  check to see the HTTP methods, headers and status codes used

xml.title: XML Introduction
xml.description: A short intro to XML and some of the key aspects you need to be aware of

xml.title: XML Namespaces
xml.description: Namespaces are an important feature of XML allowing us to clearly delineate which elements belong to which definition

javascript.title: First Steps
javascript.description: Gets you up to speed with fundamental basics of the JavaScript syntax

javascript.title: Building Blocks
javascript.description: Introduces you to conditions, loops, functions and events

javascript.title: Variable Scope
javascript.description: Really important topic, which is all part of the basics.  There are some aspects that are quite quirky, but you really should understand the difference between local and global

javascript.title: Closures
javascript.description: An extension on the variable scope section, which can initially appear confusing, however is a very powerful concept once you understand it

javascript.title: Class vs Prototype Inheritance
javascript.description: Prototype inheritance in Javascript is a bit weird for the OO purists. This reference explains how it works and compares class based inheritance in Java to prototype inheritence in JavaScript

javascript.title: Binding with Object.bind
javascript.description: This is one of the most useful things to understand in JavaScript. Due to the asynchronous nature of JavaScript, this concept can help you get out of rather tricky situations.  Again one that although confusing at first, is hugely powerful once you fully understand it

javascript.title: Promises
javascript.description: Another cool feature often used as an alternative to call back functions

javascript.title: JavaScript The Definitive Guide 6th Edition
javascript.description: I can personally recommend this book.  I purchased this and it helped me heaps and covers all the topics you require in detail

javascript.title: LearnYouNode
javascript.description: Once you start to get to grips with Javascript.  Try your hand at some server side JavaScript.  You can use this npm package to help you get up to speed with development in Node.js.  As you progress, you'll be impressed at how powerful this server is, especially with the content available from NPM

rest.title: Intro to REST
rest.description: Not usually an advocate of Wikipedia as a reliable information source, however this is the simplest explanation I can find

rest.title: Apigee Web API Design Book
rest.description: A free eBook describe various practices in the design of restful APIs.  More focussed on service development but handy to understand different implementation styles from a service consumption perspective

odata.title: OData.org
odata.description: This site has information on all the different versions of OData

odata.title: OData Ver 2.0 Specification
odata.description: Worth reading about this specific version, as this is the most commonly used currently

odata.title: Northwind Demo Service for OData 2.0
odata.description: A demo service that you can use for demo data and practice how version 2.0 of the OData specification works.  I recommend using the Postman chrome extension to simulate sample requests

odata.title: OData Ver 4.0 Specification
odata.description: Worth reading about this specific version, as this has replaced 2.0, although adoptation seems to reamin strong for 2.0

odata.title: Northwind Demo Service for OData 4.0
odata.description: A demo service that you can use for demo data and practice how version 4.0 of the OData specification works.  I recommend using the Postman chrome extension to simulate sample requests

openui5.title: OpenUI5 Home Page
openui5.description: This site has information you require for the OpenUI5 library.  I'd recommend you review the 'Developer Guide', the 'Explored' section and the the 'API Reference'.  As you progress development you will find you are constantly cross referencing these pages

openui5.title: OpenUI5 Template App
openui5.description: A simple template using Node.js to get you started.  Remember you only need to install grunt-cli once globally (using '-g') and also to change the hostname in the 'Gruntfile.js' to 'localhost'

sapui5.title: SAPUI5 Home Page
sapui5.description: This site has information you require for the SAPUI5 library.  I'd recommend you review the 'Developer Guide', the 'Explored' section and the the 'API Reference'.  As you progress development you will find you are constantly cross referencing these pages.  It will be similar to OpenUI5 however there will be support for additional controls that are not part of the OpenUI5 library

sapui5.title: Developing Web Apps with SAPUI5
sapui5.description: Self paced online course from SAP for developing web apps in SAPUI5

sapui5.title: SAPUI5 - The Comprehensive Guide
sapui5.description: Highly recommend this SAP Press book for anyone getting into UI5 development.  Admittedly it is starting to get a bit old as UI5 versions change, however a must read for anyone starting out

softwareDesign.title: Developing Software Using Design Thinking
softwareDesign.description: Self paced online course from SAP on Design Thinking

softwareDesign.title: Fiori Design Guidelines
softwareDesign.description: Analysts and developers should be familiar with these guidelines.  When building UI5 apps you should always endeavour to follow these guidelines

softwareDesign.title: Build for Rapid Prototyping of Fiori Applications
softwareDesign.description: Rapid prototyping is used to quickly design a model app that both the customer and developer can visualise.  Also provides channels for feedback and processes to assist throughout the design phase

sapGateway.title: SAP Gateway and OData Development
sapGateway.description: Can highly recommend this book from SAP Press also. Really good for anyone starting out and covers basic development and administration.  However if you want to advance I recommend you brush up on your Object Orientated ABAP skills

abap.title: ABAP 7.4 News Release
abap.description: Horst Keller updates on features available in NW 7.4

abap.title: ABAP 7.5 News Release
abap.description: Horst Keller updates on features available in NW 7.5

javascript.title: jsbin
javascript.description: A simple web based IDE for developing mini web apps for POC and training purposes.  Use this when starting out.  You can also use it to share your code (Do this for cool things you make and the things you break)

javascript.title: jsfiddle
javascript.description: An alternative web based IDE similar to jsbin

javascript.title: Node.js
javascript.description: Node.js can be used to great effect as part of your tooling to develop your Web App when used in conjunction with plugins like Grunt (task automation), Bower (package management) and Yeoman (templating).

javascript.title: Setting up NPM behind a corporate proxy
javascript.description: In case you get stuck trying to import NPM packages here is some handy info to help you if you need to configure your corporate proxy

javascript.title: Sublime Text 3
javascript.description: A really light weight text editor with heaps of plug-ins to help you develop your web applications

javascript.title: JSON View Chrome Plugin
javascript.description: When testing APIs that return JSON this handy plugin will format it and make it much easier to read

javascript.title: JSON Lint
javascript.description: When your JSON just is not well formatted this will get you out of trouble.  It is also available as a grunt task via NPM

rest.title: Postman Client
rest.description: You can use the postman to test your rest based APIs.  It can be installed standalone or as a plugin for chrome

sapui5.title: SAPUI5 Development Tools
sapui5.description: Use either Eclipse Neon or the Personel Web IDE. My personnel preference is to use Neon, but only to check out and check in my code.  I still prefer to code using my choice IDE Sublime.  You may have your own that you prefer and can use that instead

abap.title: ABAP Development Toolkit + SAP Netweaver AS ABAP Developer Edition
abap.description:
Use either Eclipse Neon and install the ABAP Development Tool Kit.  
Also find links to to download your own ABAP instance that you can install and work with at home.  I recommend installing on a VM (install over the Ubuntu operating system) as these usually expire after 6-12 months and then a new one becomes available
